nodes.name: unaligned behavior in advanced AI systems
nodes.description: Potential for powerful AI agents to act counter to human values, producing harmful or catastrophic results.
nodes.node_rationale: Identified in 1 Introduction as the overarching safety risk debate aims to solve.

nodes.name: deceptive or dishonest AI behavior in AI systems
nodes.description: Agents may intentionally provide false or misleading information to secure reward or advantage.
nodes.node_rationale: Section 5.1 cites deception as a primary failure mode debate is intended to counter.

nodes.name: high complexity tasks exceed human judgment capacity
nodes.description: Many AI tasks are too complex for direct human assessment, leading to mis-alignment during training.
nodes.node_rationale: Discussed in Section 1 and 2.3 as the core reason alignment is difficult.

nodes.name: misleading alignment signals from human feedback
aliases: systematic bias in human preference data
nodes.description: Human feedback can embed biases or errors, incentivising undesirable agent policies.
nodes.node_rationale: Section 1 and 5.1 describe how biased human supervision can create deceptive agents.

nodes.name: refuting lies is easier than constructing lies in debate game
nodes.description: Key assumption: in an adversarial debate, identifying and exposing falsehoods is cognitively cheaper than inventing them.
nodes.node_rationale: Formulated explicitly in Section 2 as the claim underlying debate’s effectiveness.

nodes.name: debate complexity equivalence to PSPACE enabling exponential information amplification
nodes.description: Theoretical result: with optimal play, polynomial-time judges in debate can solve any PSPACE problem, implying agents can amplify human capability exponentially.
nodes.node_rationale: Detailed in Section 2.2; grounds feasibility of aligning super-human agents.

nodes.name: short unbranched debates suffice due to adversarial focus
nodes.description: Optimal agents can compress large argument trees into a short sequence by focusing on the most contentious branch.
nodes.node_rationale: Illustrated with vacation example in Section 2.1.

nodes.name: adversarial debate between duplicate agents supervised by human judge
nodes.description: Design choice: two copies of a model argue opposing sides while a human judge selects the winner, incentivising truthful statements.
nodes.node_rationale: Described throughout Section 2 as the central alignment mechanism.

nodes.name: human judges reward honesty and flaw detection paradigm
nodes.description: Judges are instructed to prefer statements that reveal true, useful information and penalise misleading arguments.
nodes.node_rationale: Section 4.2 discusses instructing judges to punish misleading behaviour.

nodes.name: limiting debate length with answer precommitment reduces argument space
nodes.description: Requiring agents to state their answer before the debate and limiting turns prevents strategic argument switching and simplifies analysis.
nodes.node_rationale: Design motivation given in Section 2.1 and validated in Section 3.1 MNIST results.

nodes.name: train reward predictor to scale human debate judgments
nodes.description: To reduce human time, a model is trained to emulate human debate judgments, enabling large-scale self play.
nodes.node_rationale: Section 2.3 proposes training predictors of human reward.

nodes.name: self-play reinforcement learning of debate agents
nodes.description: Agents improve via gradient-based self play, analogous to AlphaZero, to approximate Nash-equilibrium debate strategies.
nodes.node_rationale: Implementation approach outlined in Sections 2.2 and 4.3.

nodes.name: answer precommitment before debate turns
nodes.description: Each agent must declare its answer at the start of the game and may not change it, restricting dishonest strategies.
nodes.node_rationale: Implemented in MNIST experiment (Section 3.1) and shown to reduce liar success.

nodes.name: sparse pixel MNIST debate experimental setup
nodes.description: Benchmark where agents reveal a few pixels to convince a judge classifier, testing debate without natural language.
nodes.node_rationale: Detailed in Section 3.1 as first empirical testbed.

nodes.name: human single-pixel reveal image debate website
nodes.description: Prototype web platform where human debaters reveal one pixel to convince a human judge, modelling extra knowledge.
nodes.node_rationale: Section 3.2 presents this as a planned human study.

nodes.name: sharing activations between agents for transparency
nodes.description: Agents are granted access to previous internal activations of the opponent to reduce imperfect-information issues.
nodes.node_rationale: Refinement proposed in Section 6.2.

nodes.name: training judge models to predict human reward
nodes.description: Supervised models learn to approximate human debate decisions, enabling automated large-scale training.
nodes.node_rationale: Mechanism executed in Section 3.1 where a CNN judge is trained.

nodes.name: PSPACE proof demonstrating debate power
nodes.description: Theorem 1 in Section 2.2 proves that debate with polynomial judges solves any PSPACE problem.
nodes.node_rationale: Provides formal validation of debate capability.

nodes.name: MNIST debate increases judge accuracy from 59.4% to 88.9%
nodes.description: With 6 pixel limit and precommitment, honest agents win 88.9 % vs. 59.4 % baseline judge accuracy.
nodes.node_rationale: Section 3.1 Table 2 reports quantitative validation.

nodes.name: informal human debate indicates honest agent usually wins
nodes.description: Informal trials on the prototype website show dishonest debaters rarely win when rules are understood.
nodes.node_rationale: Mentioned in Section 3.2 as preliminary human evidence.

nodes.name: adversarial debate fine-tuning to align AI models
nodes.description: During fine-tuning/RLHF, train two copies of the target model to debate each query, using human or learned judge reward to update both agents, selecting the one judged truthful.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Fine-tuning/RL phase described in Section 3 as the training stage where debate is applied.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Only proof-of-concept experiments (MNIST, pilot human) exist; no large-scale deployment yet (Sections 3 & 8).
nodes.node_rationale: Primary actionable step the paper recommends for aligning advanced AI (Section 8).

nodes.name: deploy reward predictor to automate large-scale debate training
nodes.description: Train and integrate a neural reward model that emulates human debate judgments, allowing millions of automated debate rounds with minimal human oversight.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Implemented alongside debate fine-tuning to replace most human evaluations (Section 2.3).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Demonstrated only on MNIST classifier; human-grade predictors remain experimental (Section 3.1).
nodes.node_rationale: Enables scalable application of debate without prohibitive human cost.
